natural problem: The sides of rectangle $ABCD$ have lengths $10$ and $11$. An equilateral triangle is drawn so that no point of the triangle lies outside $ABCD$.  Find the maximum possible area of such a triangle.
natural solution: Place the rectangle in the complex plane so that one corner is at the origin, and the sides align with the real and imaginary axis.

To maximize the area of the triangle, we let one vertex of the triangle be at the origin, and we let the other two vertices ($p$ and $q$) lie on the sides of the rectangle, as shown. [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm);

pair A, B, C, D, P, Q; A = (0,0); B = (11,0); C = (11,10); D = (0,10); Q = extension(C, D, rotate(60)*(B), rotate(60)*(C)); P = rotate(-60)*(Q); draw(A--B--C--D--cycle); draw(A--P--Q--cycle); label("$0$", A, SW);

label("$p$", P, E); label("$q$", Q, N); label("$11$", B, SE); label("$10i$", D, NW); [/asy] Then $p = 11 + yi$ for some real number $y.$  Also, \begin{align} q &= e^{\pi i/3} p \\ &= \left( \frac{1}{2} + i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right) (11 + yi) \\

&= \left( \frac{11}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} y \right) + i \left( \frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} \right). \end{align}Since the imaginary part of $q$ is 10, \[\frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} = 10,\]so $y = 20 - 11 \sqrt{3}.$

Then the area of the triangle is \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left|11 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3}) i\right|^2 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left(11^2 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3})^2\right) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (884 - 440 \sqrt{3}) \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D T :: "(real * real)"
and rec_area :: "real"
and tri_area :: "real"
assumes h0 : "A = (0, 0)"
and h1 : "B = (10, 0)"
and h2 : "C = (10, 11)"
and h3 : "D = (0, 11)"
and h4 : "rec_area = dist A B * dist B C"
and h5 : "\<forall> T. is_equilateral_triangle T \<and> T \<subseteq> {A, B, C, D} \<longrightarrow> tri_area \<le> area T"
shows  "tri_area = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sides of rectangle $ABCD$ have lengths $10$ and $11$. An equilateral triangle is drawn so that no point of the triangle lies outside $ABCD$.  Find the maximum possible area of such a triangle. The final Answer is 221 \sqrt{3} - 330
 ### Proof
 Place the rectangle in the complex plane so that one corner is at the origin, and the sides align with the real and imaginary axis.
 To maximize the area of the triangle, we let one vertex of the triangle be at the origin, and we let the other two vertices ($p$ and $q$) lie on the sides of the rectangle, as shown. [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm);
 pair A, B, C, D, P, Q; A = (0,0); B = (11,0); C = (11,10); D = (0,10); Q = extension(C, D, rotate(60)*(B), rotate(60)*(C)); P = rotate(-60)*(Q); draw(A--B--C--D--cycle); draw(A--P--Q--cycle); label("$0$", A, SW);
 label("$p$", P, E); label("$q$", Q, N); label("$11$", B, SE); label("$10i$", D, NW); [/asy] Then $p = 11 + yi$ for some real number $y.$  Also, \begin{align} q &= e^{\pi i/3} p \\ &= \left( \frac{1}{2} + i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right) (11 + yi) \\
 &= \left( \frac{11}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} y \right) + i \left( \frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} \right). \end{align}Since the imaginary part of $q$ is 10, \[\frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} = 10,\]so $y = 20 - 11 \sqrt{3}.$
 Then the area of the triangle is \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left|11 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3}) i\right|^2 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left(11^2 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3})^2\right) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (884 - 440 \sqrt{3}) \\
 &= \boxed{221 \sqrt{3} - 330}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D T :: "(real * real)"
and rec_area :: "real"
and tri_area :: "real"
assumes h0 : "A = (0, 0)"
and h1 : "B = (10, 0)"
and h2 : "C = (10, 11)"
and h3 : "D = (0, 11)"
and h4 : "rec_area = dist A B * dist B C"
and h5 : "\<forall> T. is_equilateral_triangle T \<and> T \<subseteq> {A, B, C, D} \<longrightarrow> tri_area \<le> area T"
shows  "tri_area = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider a rectangle with vertices $A (0, 0)$, $B (10, 0)$, $C (10, 11)$, and $D (0, 11)$. The area of the rectangle is given by the product of the distance between points $A$ and $B$ and the distance between points $B$ and $C$. Now consider any equilateral triangle $T$ that fits within this rectangle. The maximum possible area of such a triangle is $221\sqrt{3} - 330$ square units.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real \<times> real"
and rectangle_area :: "real \<times> real \<Rightarrow> real \<times> real \<Rightarrow> real"
and triangle_area :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "rectangle_area A D = 10 * 11"
and h1 : "triangle_area x \<le> rectangle_area A D"
shows  "triangle_area x = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sides of rectangle $ABCD$ have lengths $10$ and $11$. An equilateral triangle is drawn so that no point of the triangle lies outside $ABCD$.  Find the maximum possible area of such a triangle. The final Answer is 221 \sqrt{3} - 330
 ### Proof
 Place the rectangle in the complex plane so that one corner is at the origin, and the sides align with the real and imaginary axis.
 To maximize the area of the triangle, we let one vertex of the triangle be at the origin, and we let the other two vertices ($p$ and $q$) lie on the sides of the rectangle, as shown. [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm);
 pair A, B, C, D, P, Q; A = (0,0); B = (11,0); C = (11,10); D = (0,10); Q = extension(C, D, rotate(60)*(B), rotate(60)*(C)); P = rotate(-60)*(Q); draw(A--B--C--D--cycle); draw(A--P--Q--cycle); label("$0$", A, SW);
 label("$p$", P, E); label("$q$", Q, N); label("$11$", B, SE); label("$10i$", D, NW); [/asy] Then $p = 11 + yi$ for some real number $y.$  Also, \begin{align} q &= e^{\pi i/3} p \\ &= \left( \frac{1}{2} + i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right) (11 + yi) \\
 &= \left( \frac{11}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} y \right) + i \left( \frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} \right). \end{align}Since the imaginary part of $q$ is 10, \[\frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} = 10,\]so $y = 20 - 11 \sqrt{3}.$
 Then the area of the triangle is \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left|11 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3}) i\right|^2 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left(11^2 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3})^2\right) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (884 - 440 \sqrt{3}) \\
 &= \boxed{221 \sqrt{3} - 330}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real \<times> real"
and rectangle_area :: "real \<times> real \<Rightarrow> real \<times> real \<Rightarrow> real"
and triangle_area :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "rectangle_area A D = 10 * 11"
and h1 : "triangle_area x \<le> rectangle_area A D"
shows  "triangle_area x = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a rectangle AD with an area of 110 square units, find the area of a triangle x such that it is less than or equal to the area of the rectangle. The final answer for the area of the triangle is $221\sqrt{3} - 330$ square units.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "rectangle a b c"
and h1 : "a = 10"
and h2 : "b = 11"
and h3 : "equilateral_triangle c"
and h4 : "\<forall> point. point in c \<longrightarrow> point in a"
shows  "area c = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sides of rectangle $ABCD$ have lengths $10$ and $11$. An equilateral triangle is drawn so that no point of the triangle lies outside $ABCD$.  Find the maximum possible area of such a triangle. The final Answer is 221 \sqrt{3} - 330
 ### Proof
 Place the rectangle in the complex plane so that one corner is at the origin, and the sides align with the real and imaginary axis.
 To maximize the area of the triangle, we let one vertex of the triangle be at the origin, and we let the other two vertices ($p$ and $q$) lie on the sides of the rectangle, as shown. [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm);
 pair A, B, C, D, P, Q; A = (0,0); B = (11,0); C = (11,10); D = (0,10); Q = extension(C, D, rotate(60)*(B), rotate(60)*(C)); P = rotate(-60)*(Q); draw(A--B--C--D--cycle); draw(A--P--Q--cycle); label("$0$", A, SW);
 label("$p$", P, E); label("$q$", Q, N); label("$11$", B, SE); label("$10i$", D, NW); [/asy] Then $p = 11 + yi$ for some real number $y.$  Also, \begin{align} q &= e^{\pi i/3} p \\ &= \left( \frac{1}{2} + i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right) (11 + yi) \\
 &= \left( \frac{11}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} y \right) + i \left( \frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} \right). \end{align}Since the imaginary part of $q$ is 10, \[\frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} = 10,\]so $y = 20 - 11 \sqrt{3}.$
 Then the area of the triangle is \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left|11 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3}) i\right|^2 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left(11^2 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3})^2\right) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (884 - 440 \sqrt{3}) \\
 &= \boxed{221 \sqrt{3} - 330}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "rectangle a b c"
and h1 : "a = 10"
and h2 : "b = 11"
and h3 : "equilateral_triangle c"
and h4 : "\<forall> point. point in c \<longrightarrow> point in a"
shows  "area c = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Suppose there is a rectangle with sides of lengths 10 and 11, and an equilateral triangle is contained within this rectangle. If every point of the triangle is also a point in the rectangle, find the area of the triangle. The final answer is $221\sqrt{3} - 330$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real" and triangle_area :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "fst B - fst A = 10"
and h1 : "snd D - snd A = 11"
and h2 : "\<forall> a b. triangle_area a b = sqrt 3 / 4 * a * b"
and h3 : "\<forall> a b. a \<le> 10 \<and> b \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> triangle_area a b \<le> triangle_area 10 11"
shows  "triangle_area 10 11 = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sides of rectangle $ABCD$ have lengths $10$ and $11$. An equilateral triangle is drawn so that no point of the triangle lies outside $ABCD$.  Find the maximum possible area of such a triangle. The final Answer is 221 \sqrt{3} - 330
 ### Proof
 Place the rectangle in the complex plane so that one corner is at the origin, and the sides align with the real and imaginary axis.
 To maximize the area of the triangle, we let one vertex of the triangle be at the origin, and we let the other two vertices ($p$ and $q$) lie on the sides of the rectangle, as shown. [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm);
 pair A, B, C, D, P, Q; A = (0,0); B = (11,0); C = (11,10); D = (0,10); Q = extension(C, D, rotate(60)*(B), rotate(60)*(C)); P = rotate(-60)*(Q); draw(A--B--C--D--cycle); draw(A--P--Q--cycle); label("$0$", A, SW);
 label("$p$", P, E); label("$q$", Q, N); label("$11$", B, SE); label("$10i$", D, NW); [/asy] Then $p = 11 + yi$ for some real number $y.$  Also, \begin{align} q &= e^{\pi i/3} p \\ &= \left( \frac{1}{2} + i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right) (11 + yi) \\
 &= \left( \frac{11}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} y \right) + i \left( \frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} \right). \end{align}Since the imaginary part of $q$ is 10, \[\frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} = 10,\]so $y = 20 - 11 \sqrt{3}.$
 Then the area of the triangle is \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left|11 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3}) i\right|^2 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left(11^2 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3})^2\right) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (884 - 440 \sqrt{3}) \\
 &= \boxed{221 \sqrt{3} - 330}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real" and triangle_area :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "fst B - fst A = 10"
and h1 : "snd D - snd A = 11"
and h2 : "\<forall> a b. triangle_area a b = sqrt 3 / 4 * a * b"
and h3 : "\<forall> a b. a \<le> 10 \<and> b \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> triangle_area a b \<le> triangle_area 10 11"
shows  "triangle_area 10 11 = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given a rectangle with length 10 units (difference between the x-coordinates of points A and B) and width 11 units (difference between the y-coordinates of points A and D), and the area of a triangle with base $a$ and height $b$ is given by $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}ab$, find the area of the largest possible triangle that can be inscribed in the rectangle. The final answer is $221\sqrt{3} - 330$ square units.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 10"
and h1 : "b = 11"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 1 \<longrightarrow> (b*x) powr 2 + ((a - b)*x) powr 2 \<le> b powr 2"
shows  "\<exists>A. A = b powr 2 * sqrt 3 / 4 \<and> A = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sides of rectangle $ABCD$ have lengths $10$ and $11$. An equilateral triangle is drawn so that no point of the triangle lies outside $ABCD$.  Find the maximum possible area of such a triangle. The final Answer is 221 \sqrt{3} - 330
 ### Proof
 Place the rectangle in the complex plane so that one corner is at the origin, and the sides align with the real and imaginary axis.
 To maximize the area of the triangle, we let one vertex of the triangle be at the origin, and we let the other two vertices ($p$ and $q$) lie on the sides of the rectangle, as shown. [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm);
 pair A, B, C, D, P, Q; A = (0,0); B = (11,0); C = (11,10); D = (0,10); Q = extension(C, D, rotate(60)*(B), rotate(60)*(C)); P = rotate(-60)*(Q); draw(A--B--C--D--cycle); draw(A--P--Q--cycle); label("$0$", A, SW);
 label("$p$", P, E); label("$q$", Q, N); label("$11$", B, SE); label("$10i$", D, NW); [/asy] Then $p = 11 + yi$ for some real number $y.$  Also, \begin{align} q &= e^{\pi i/3} p \\ &= \left( \frac{1}{2} + i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right) (11 + yi) \\
 &= \left( \frac{11}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} y \right) + i \left( \frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} \right). \end{align}Since the imaginary part of $q$ is 10, \[\frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} = 10,\]so $y = 20 - 11 \sqrt{3}.$
 Then the area of the triangle is \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left|11 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3}) i\right|^2 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left(11^2 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3})^2\right) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (884 - 440 \sqrt{3}) \\
 &= \boxed{221 \sqrt{3} - 330}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 10"
and h1 : "b = 11"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 1 \<longrightarrow> (b*x) powr 2 + ((a - b)*x) powr 2 \<le> b powr 2"
shows  "\<exists>A. A = b powr 2 * sqrt 3 / 4 \<and> A = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given that $a = 10$ and $b = 11$, prove that for all $x$ between $0$ and $1$, the following inequality is satisfied: $(bx)^2 + ((a-b)x)^2 \leq b^2$. Then, show that there exists a value $A$ such that $A$ equals $\frac{b^2 \sqrt{3}}{4}$ and $A$ also equals $221\sqrt{3} - 330$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: real
assumes h0 : "A = 10"
and h1 : "B = 11"
and h2 : "C = sqrt (3) / 4 * A * A"
and h3 : "D = sqrt (3) / 4 * B * B"
shows  "C \<le> D"
and "Max {C, D} = 221 * sqrt (3) - 330"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sides of rectangle $ABCD$ have lengths $10$ and $11$. An equilateral triangle is drawn so that no point of the triangle lies outside $ABCD$.  Find the maximum possible area of such a triangle. The final Answer is 221 \sqrt{3} - 330
 ### Proof
 Place the rectangle in the complex plane so that one corner is at the origin, and the sides align with the real and imaginary axis.
 To maximize the area of the triangle, we let one vertex of the triangle be at the origin, and we let the other two vertices ($p$ and $q$) lie on the sides of the rectangle, as shown. [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm);
 pair A, B, C, D, P, Q; A = (0,0); B = (11,0); C = (11,10); D = (0,10); Q = extension(C, D, rotate(60)*(B), rotate(60)*(C)); P = rotate(-60)*(Q); draw(A--B--C--D--cycle); draw(A--P--Q--cycle); label("$0$", A, SW);
 label("$p$", P, E); label("$q$", Q, N); label("$11$", B, SE); label("$10i$", D, NW); [/asy] Then $p = 11 + yi$ for some real number $y.$  Also, \begin{align} q &= e^{\pi i/3} p \\ &= \left( \frac{1}{2} + i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right) (11 + yi) \\
 &= \left( \frac{11}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} y \right) + i \left( \frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} \right). \end{align}Since the imaginary part of $q$ is 10, \[\frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} = 10,\]so $y = 20 - 11 \sqrt{3}.$
 Then the area of the triangle is \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left|11 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3}) i\right|^2 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left(11^2 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3})^2\right) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (884 - 440 \sqrt{3}) \\
 &= \boxed{221 \sqrt{3} - 330}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: real
assumes h0 : "A = 10"
and h1 : "B = 11"
and h2 : "C = sqrt (3) / 4 * A * A"
and h3 : "D = sqrt (3) / 4 * B * B"
shows  "C \<le> D"
and "Max {C, D} = 221 * sqrt (3) - 330"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Let A be 10 and B be 11. Find the values of C and D where C is the result of the formula $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \times A^2$ and D is the result of the formula $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \times B^2$. Show that C is less than or equal to D and the maximum value between C and D is $221\sqrt{3} - 330$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real^2" and T :: "(real^2) set"
assumes h0 : "rectangle A B C D"
and h1 : "distance A B = 10"
and h2 : "distance B C = 11"
and h3 : "equilateral_triangle T"
and h4 : "T \<subseteq> convex hull {A, B, C, D}"
shows  "area T \<le> 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sides of rectangle $ABCD$ have lengths $10$ and $11$. An equilateral triangle is drawn so that no point of the triangle lies outside $ABCD$.  Find the maximum possible area of such a triangle. The final Answer is 221 \sqrt{3} - 330
 ### Proof
 Place the rectangle in the complex plane so that one corner is at the origin, and the sides align with the real and imaginary axis.
 To maximize the area of the triangle, we let one vertex of the triangle be at the origin, and we let the other two vertices ($p$ and $q$) lie on the sides of the rectangle, as shown. [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm);
 pair A, B, C, D, P, Q; A = (0,0); B = (11,0); C = (11,10); D = (0,10); Q = extension(C, D, rotate(60)*(B), rotate(60)*(C)); P = rotate(-60)*(Q); draw(A--B--C--D--cycle); draw(A--P--Q--cycle); label("$0$", A, SW);
 label("$p$", P, E); label("$q$", Q, N); label("$11$", B, SE); label("$10i$", D, NW); [/asy] Then $p = 11 + yi$ for some real number $y.$  Also, \begin{align} q &= e^{\pi i/3} p \\ &= \left( \frac{1}{2} + i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right) (11 + yi) \\
 &= \left( \frac{11}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} y \right) + i \left( \frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} \right). \end{align}Since the imaginary part of $q$ is 10, \[\frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} = 10,\]so $y = 20 - 11 \sqrt{3}.$
 Then the area of the triangle is \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left|11 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3}) i\right|^2 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left(11^2 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3})^2\right) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (884 - 440 \sqrt{3}) \\
 &= \boxed{221 \sqrt{3} - 330}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real^2" and T :: "(real^2) set"
assumes h0 : "rectangle A B C D"
and h1 : "distance A B = 10"
and h2 : "distance B C = 11"
and h3 : "equilateral_triangle T"
and h4 : "T \<subseteq> convex hull {A, B, C, D}"
shows  "area T \<le> 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Assume there is a rectangle with vertices A, B, C, D, where the distance between A and B is 10 units, and the distance between B and C is 11 units. Within this rectangle, there is an equilateral triangle T. Find the maximum possible area of triangle T. The final answer is $221\sqrt{3} - 330$ square units.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real*real" and triangle_area rectangle_area :: real
assumes h0 : "rectangle_area = 10 * 11"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y z. is_equilateral_triangle x y z \<longrightarrow> triangle_area \<le> rectangle_area"
shows  "triangle_area = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sides of rectangle $ABCD$ have lengths $10$ and $11$. An equilateral triangle is drawn so that no point of the triangle lies outside $ABCD$.  Find the maximum possible area of such a triangle. The final Answer is 221 \sqrt{3} - 330
 ### Proof
 Place the rectangle in the complex plane so that one corner is at the origin, and the sides align with the real and imaginary axis.
 To maximize the area of the triangle, we let one vertex of the triangle be at the origin, and we let the other two vertices ($p$ and $q$) lie on the sides of the rectangle, as shown. [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm);
 pair A, B, C, D, P, Q; A = (0,0); B = (11,0); C = (11,10); D = (0,10); Q = extension(C, D, rotate(60)*(B), rotate(60)*(C)); P = rotate(-60)*(Q); draw(A--B--C--D--cycle); draw(A--P--Q--cycle); label("$0$", A, SW);
 label("$p$", P, E); label("$q$", Q, N); label("$11$", B, SE); label("$10i$", D, NW); [/asy] Then $p = 11 + yi$ for some real number $y.$  Also, \begin{align} q &= e^{\pi i/3} p \\ &= \left( \frac{1}{2} + i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right) (11 + yi) \\
 &= \left( \frac{11}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} y \right) + i \left( \frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} \right). \end{align}Since the imaginary part of $q$ is 10, \[\frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} = 10,\]so $y = 20 - 11 \sqrt{3}.$
 Then the area of the triangle is \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left|11 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3}) i\right|^2 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left(11^2 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3})^2\right) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (884 - 440 \sqrt{3}) \\
 &= \boxed{221 \sqrt{3} - 330}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real*real" and triangle_area rectangle_area :: real
assumes h0 : "rectangle_area = 10 * 11"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y z. is_equilateral_triangle x y z \<longrightarrow> triangle_area \<le> rectangle_area"
shows  "triangle_area = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: The area of a rectangle is given as $10 \times 11$. An equilateral triangle is defined such that its area is always less than or equal to that of the rectangle. Find the exact area of the equilateral triangle. The final answer is $221 \times \sqrt{3} - 330$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: real
assumes h0 : "A = 10"
and h1 : "B = 11"
and h2 : "\<forall> x y. x \<le> A \<and> y \<le> B \<longrightarrow> exists_triangle x y"
shows  "max_triangle_area A B = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sides of rectangle $ABCD$ have lengths $10$ and $11$. An equilateral triangle is drawn so that no point of the triangle lies outside $ABCD$.  Find the maximum possible area of such a triangle. The final Answer is 221 \sqrt{3} - 330
 ### Proof
 Place the rectangle in the complex plane so that one corner is at the origin, and the sides align with the real and imaginary axis.
 To maximize the area of the triangle, we let one vertex of the triangle be at the origin, and we let the other two vertices ($p$ and $q$) lie on the sides of the rectangle, as shown. [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm);
 pair A, B, C, D, P, Q; A = (0,0); B = (11,0); C = (11,10); D = (0,10); Q = extension(C, D, rotate(60)*(B), rotate(60)*(C)); P = rotate(-60)*(Q); draw(A--B--C--D--cycle); draw(A--P--Q--cycle); label("$0$", A, SW);
 label("$p$", P, E); label("$q$", Q, N); label("$11$", B, SE); label("$10i$", D, NW); [/asy] Then $p = 11 + yi$ for some real number $y.$  Also, \begin{align} q &= e^{\pi i/3} p \\ &= \left( \frac{1}{2} + i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right) (11 + yi) \\
 &= \left( \frac{11}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} y \right) + i \left( \frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} \right). \end{align}Since the imaginary part of $q$ is 10, \[\frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} = 10,\]so $y = 20 - 11 \sqrt{3}.$
 Then the area of the triangle is \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left|11 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3}) i\right|^2 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left(11^2 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3})^2\right) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (884 - 440 \sqrt{3}) \\
 &= \boxed{221 \sqrt{3} - 330}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: real
assumes h0 : "A = 10"
and h1 : "B = 11"
and h2 : "\<forall> x y. x \<le> A \<and> y \<le> B \<longrightarrow> exists_triangle x y"
shows  "max_triangle_area A B = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that the lengths of two sides of a triangle are at most 10 (A) and 11 (B) respectively, and a triangle can be formed with any lengths equal to or less than A and B, find the maximum area of such a triangle. The final answer is $221\sqrt{3} - 330$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real and area_rectangle area_triangle :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "a = 10"
and h1 : "b = 11"
and h2 : "\<forall> a b. area_rectangle a b = a * b"
and h3 : "area_triangle a b = (sqrt 3 / 4) * a * b"
shows  "area_triangle a b = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sides of rectangle $ABCD$ have lengths $10$ and $11$. An equilateral triangle is drawn so that no point of the triangle lies outside $ABCD$.  Find the maximum possible area of such a triangle. The final Answer is 221 \sqrt{3} - 330
 ### Proof
 Place the rectangle in the complex plane so that one corner is at the origin, and the sides align with the real and imaginary axis.
 To maximize the area of the triangle, we let one vertex of the triangle be at the origin, and we let the other two vertices ($p$ and $q$) lie on the sides of the rectangle, as shown. [asy] unitsize(0.4 cm);
 pair A, B, C, D, P, Q; A = (0,0); B = (11,0); C = (11,10); D = (0,10); Q = extension(C, D, rotate(60)*(B), rotate(60)*(C)); P = rotate(-60)*(Q); draw(A--B--C--D--cycle); draw(A--P--Q--cycle); label("$0$", A, SW);
 label("$p$", P, E); label("$q$", Q, N); label("$11$", B, SE); label("$10i$", D, NW); [/asy] Then $p = 11 + yi$ for some real number $y.$  Also, \begin{align} q &= e^{\pi i/3} p \\ &= \left( \frac{1}{2} + i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right) (11 + yi) \\
 &= \left( \frac{11}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} y \right) + i \left( \frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} \right). \end{align}Since the imaginary part of $q$ is 10, \[\frac{y}{2} + \frac{11 \sqrt{3}}{2} = 10,\]so $y = 20 - 11 \sqrt{3}.$
 Then the area of the triangle is \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left|11 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3}) i\right|^2 &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \left(11^2 + (20 - 11 \sqrt{3})^2\right) \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (884 - 440 \sqrt{3}) \\
 &= \boxed{221 \sqrt{3} - 330}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real and area_rectangle area_triangle :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "a = 10"
and h1 : "b = 11"
and h2 : "\<forall> a b. area_rectangle a b = a * b"
and h3 : "area_triangle a b = (sqrt 3 / 4) * a * b"
shows  "area_triangle a b = 221 * sqrt 3 - 330"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given that the area of a rectangle with sides of length $a$ and $b$ is given by the formula $a * b$ and that the area of a triangle with sides of length $a$ and $b$ is given by the formula $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} * a * b$, find the area of a triangle where $a = 10$ and $b = 11$. The final answer is $221\sqrt{3} - 330$.
